awd_titl_txt: DMS-EPSRC: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Dynamics of Vibro-Impact Systems with Applications in Energy Harvesting
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid development of electronic devices, such as wearable and wireless sensors networks integrated into the Internet of Things, has created the need for efficient, environmentally-friendly energy generators capable of recharging batteries to prolong their lifespan. Vibrational energy harvesting, a process for scavenging energy from natural or forced vibrations such as structural movement or human activity, provides a promising  means for this energy generation. This grant leverages a synergy between mathematical innovation and data-driven modeling, yielding transformative tools for advancing highly promising yet surprisingly complex systems for energy harvesting and targeted energy transfer. The research contributes to future economic and environmental impacts by supporting the widespread use of self-recharging wireless sensors, such as on bridges, buildings, and off-shore renewable energy generators. Powering wireless devices in health and structural safety monitoring systems will significantly reduce operation and maintenance costs associated with the wired technologies. The environmental contributions are therefore two-fold: direct, as a green energy device, and indirect through enabling effective diagnostics and prognostics in the renewable energy sector.
 
The goals of this grant address gaps and opportunities in mathematical developments and in practical applications for impact-based engineering devices and systems with non-smooth dynamics, critical for understanding the harvesting of vibrational energy. The main research objective of this grant is to develop a universal suite of mathematical methodologies for the analysis and optimized performance of deterministic and stochastic non-smooth engineering systems. These approaches are pursued with a focus on practical engineering models of vibro-impacting energy harvesting systems and nonlinear dynamic dampers, within the broad area of targeted energy transfer. Integrating novel nonlinear, stochastic, and computational approaches with experimental and real-world data both for energy harvesting and for devices that mitigate vibration will pave new pathways for analysis-based design and model validation. Synergistic connections between analysis, computations and data-driven mathematical innovation are pursued both to drive new mathematical approaches and to obtain practical predictions for device design. This grant will also serve as an excellent cross-disciplinary training ground for the involved postdocs and graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of the proposed research is to drive innovation through a deeper understanding of vibro-impact (VI) energy harvesting (EH) with applications to targeted energy transfer (TET) and vibration mitigation. The research focuses on areas largely unexplored by foundational design-based, data-informed dynamical analyses, complemented by computations, leading to significant advancements: 1) Novel applied analyses and computational methods for forced stochastic and deterministic nonlinear non-smooth systems. These methods are applied to models of vibro-impact energy harvesters (VI-EH) and vibro-impact nonlinear energy sinks (VI-NES) to identify design parameters for optimal performance. 2) A pioneering framework for VI dynamics, integrating dynamical analyses, computational methods, and experimental data.

Inspired by experimental data from our UK collaborator, we apply computational modeling and non-smooth analyses to guide and test proposed designs. This synergistic approach enables realistic design of new VI-based systems, exploiting non-smooth benefits such as passive or semi-active energy capture and energy transmission. This comprehensive methodology provides a transformative tool for designing efficient VI-EH and VI-NES systems. The work addresses existing deficiencies in the field, helping to overcome obstacles to the broader adoption of wireless technologies in everyday life. Data from our UK collaborator and industry have motivated further stochastic and multi-mode analyses.

A website reports the activities of the research collaboration, including publications and significant conference contributions. The project has provided excellent cross-disciplinary training for five postdocs and a graduate student, with over 50% from under-represented groups. Seventeen undergraduates participated in summer programs (NSF-REU) during the grant period, with over 40% from under-represented groups. All five of the postdocs have gone on to academic faculty positions, and the REU summer students are applying for or are pursuing advanced degrees.  Our group and collaborators have maintained a significant presence at major conferences in applied dynamical systems and engineering, particularly in non-smooth and nonlinear dynamics. The work on a novel global analysis for non-smooth, impacting systems has been invited for publication as a SIAM News Article for the broader applied modeling community, which we expect to appear in 2025.

Our work also established a systematic framework for analyzing the interplay of smooth and non-smooth bifurcations. This approach provides insights into energy harvesting efficiency, identifying transitions between efficient and inefficient regimes, characterizing the role of asymmetries, and mapping behaviors across a broad parameter space. These findings allow for better predictions of how parameter changes influence system performance.

One major breakthrough is our new approach to path integration, which greatly improves computational efficiency for a method previously considered impractical. This method, applied to both smooth and impact dynamics, reduces computational costs and enables the study of a wider range of complex behaviors.

To address realistic impacts, we developed a new soft impact model that better aligns with experimental results. We applied this model and, with additional data from experiments at the University of Southampton, we compared impacting dynamics across different materials and capsule geometries. This has significantly improved the realism of our models and enabled exploration of experimental impact behaviors.

In the context of the VINES system for targeted energy transfer (TET), we introduced a semi-analytical method providing exact solutions in areas previously constrained by limited parameter ranges. This method expands the range of accessible dynamics and reveals unexpected behaviors. Notably, phase noise was shown to widen the range of dynamics favorable to energy transfer, enhancing understanding of energy harvesting efficiency.

For global dynamics in non-smooth systems, we developed a new semi-analytical approach using composite maps with cobweb representations. This innovation enables computer-assisted global analysis through conservative auxiliary maps that capture extreme bounds of the dynamics. By studying energetically favorable states, particularly in grazing and stochastic settings, we demonstrated its value for understanding bi-stability and predicting global behavior.

Motivated by experiments, we studied the influence of dry friction in VI-EH dynamics. Friction can reduce some complex behavior, such as bifurcations to chaotic behavior, and introduce others  like chattering and multi-stable complexity. Our analysis classified parameter regimes where friction mitigates negative effects and uncovered bifurcation sequences absent in frictionless systems. Combined with our global dynamics framework, this work informs optimized design of VI-EH devices.

We also developed a semi-analytical stochastic map-based approach to examine randomness in systems near grazing bifurcations. For example, we studied how a random restitution coefficient affects energy output. By directly calculating energy output distributions relative to randomness, this approach offers an efficient alternative to costly Monte Carlo simulations.

Together, these advances provide a comprehensive understanding of vibro-impact systems by integrating theory, experiments, and advanced computations. Moving forward, we aim to develop data-driven stochastic electro-mechanical prototypes of VI-EH devices, incorporating further measurements and refining predictions. This work marks a major step toward efficient and reliable energy harvesting and transfer technologies.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/25/2024
Modified by: Rachel A Kuske

Images (1 of )
  • Friction removes chaotic regions, which occur in left panel with no friction, and shifts preferable ranges of energy output as in right panel
    RACHEL KUSKE
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Rachel A Kuske
    Friction in VI-EH
  • Schematics for: a) VI- energy harvester and b) VI-based TET;Experimental data provided by UK collaborator, collected from: c) EH-device mounted to d) large amplitude , low frequency platform and e) low amplitude, high frequency TET testing rig.
    RACHEL KUSKE
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Rachel A Kuske
    Schematics and experimental rigs
  • Left: Stochastic phase shifts and expands desirable region with alternating impacts for TET; Right: Stochastic phase shifts and expands region with desirable TET (yellow)
    RACHEL KUSKE
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Rachel A Kuske
    Stochastic phase in TET
  • Left: Curves for Composite map (a) and auxiliary map (b) giving subsequent impact velocities ￼ yield global attracting regions for these velocities, informing energy output; Right: Transients for probability densities computed with new efficient path integral method for impacting systems
    RACHEL KUSKE
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Rachel A Kuske
    Computer Assisted Global Analysis and Efficient Path Integral Methods
